newsitem.title: HUNGARY: HUNGARY SEES STRONG U.S. ROLE WITH CLINTON VICTORY.
newsitem.headline: HUNGARY SEES STRONG U.S. ROLE WITH CLINTON VICTORY.

text.p: Hungary on Tuesday said it welcomed U.S. President Bill Clinton's election victory and looked forward to a continued strong U.S. presence in Eastern Europe as the region prepares for NATO enlargement.

"We look forward to the U.S. role continuing internationally in terms of maintaining democratic values, helping solve local crises and determined support for the enlargement of NATO," foreign ministry spokesman Gabor Szentivanyi told Reuters.

Hungary plays host to thousands of U.S. troops at the U.S. Army's forward base for its IFOR peace implementation force for Bosnia at Taszar in southern Hungary and was a close adviser to Clinton during the lead-up to the Dayton conference on the former Yugoslavia.
Szentivanyi said the U.S.'s part in sponsoring the Dayton peace agreement ending the four-year war in the neighbouring former Yugoslavia had been invaluable.
"It shows there is a need for a U.S. involvement and it's very well reflected by the postiton of other European powers."
Szentivanyi said he saw Clinton as a strong supporter of Hungary's efforts to join NATO.
"We welcome the very determined position of this Administration and Congressional support for the enlargement of NATO and also our efforts to join the European Union."
He added that Hungary was comfortable with the new U.S. Congress.
"We enjoy bipartisan support from within Congress so we have no problem with the composition," he said.
Congress is the only Western legislature which has specifically named Hungary, along with Poland and the Czech Republic, as the first countries which should be allowed to join the Alliance.
Szentivanyi added that Hungarian relations with the Clinton Administration were more than just cordial.
"We have such close cooperation over Dayton and NATO enlargement I can see a strategic alliance developing," he said.
Hungarian newspapers concentrated on the low turnout and Clinton's ability to adapt to cirumstances as the the most noteworthy features of the election.

"The key to Clinton's success, despite Dole's best efforts, lies in his personality," said the daily Magyar Nemzet. "After the first two years of failed liberal politics he was able to take on conservative policies and that's what got him re-elected "
The centrist Magyar Hirlap believed neither candidate had inspired people to go out and vote in large numbers.
"The lack of interest was a dominating feature of this election," it said.
